data.title: RICCIARDO AND MÁRQUEZ IN GOOD PLACE FOR NOMINATION FOR LAUREUS WORLD BREAKTHROUGH AWARD BUT THE COMPETITION IS TIGHTER THAN EVER
data.meta_description: RICCIARDO AND MÁRQUEZ IN GOOD PLACE FOR LAUREUS WORLD BREAKTHROUGH AWARD NOMINATION BUT COMPETITION IS TIGHTER THAN EVER Strong support for FIFA World Cup Gold Crampon James Rodriguez Chinese swimming sensation Shen Duo wins six medals
data.text:
RICCIARDO AND MÁRQUEZ IN GOOD PLACE FOR LAUREUS WORLD BREAKTHROUGH AWARD NOMINATION BUT COMPETITION IS TIGHTER THAN EVER

Strong support for FIFA World Cup Gold Crampon James Rodriguez

Chinese swimming sensation Shen Duo wins six gold medals at Youth Olympics

Roger Federer inspires Switzerland to its first-ever Davis Cup victory

The world's media votes for the SIX nominees for the Laureus Breakthrough Award

The Laureus World Sports Awards will take place in Shanghai from April 13 to 15

LONDON, January 15, 2015 – Two young motorsport stars, Australian Formula 1 driver Daniel Ricciardo and Spanish Moto3 world champion Alex Márquez, are among the favorites to be nominated for the 2015 Laureus World Breakthrough of the Year Award.

The six nominees for this prestigious award will be announced on February 11, following a vote by the world's media. To make the list, Ricciardo and Márquez will face some of the most talented newcomers in world sport, including FIFA World Cup leading scorer James Rodriguez, Chinese swimmer Shen Duo, the most successful athlete in the Youth Olympic Games. , and 11-year-old American golf prodigy Lucy Li, the youngest player to ever qualify for the US Women's Open.

The Swiss tennis team, inspired by Roger Federer, could also be there, after its very first Davis Cup victory.

The six nominees for the Laureus World Breakthrough of the Year Award are chosen by the Laureus Global Media Selection Panel, which includes the leading online sports editors, writers, broadcasters and journalists from around the world. The final winner will be elected by secret ballot by the ultimate sports jury, the 47 members of the Laureus World Sports Academy: the living legends of sport paying tribute to the greatest athletes of today

Among the sportsmen and women who will hope to be one of the six nominated for the Laureus Breakthrough of the Year, we can cite:

Daniel Ricciardo, 25, took over from fellow Australian Mark Webber at Red Bull and made a significant impact, winning three Grand Prix during his first year (Canada, Hungary and Belgium) and finishing ahead of his teammate and four-time world champion Sebastian Vettel in the Drivers' Championship. Ricciardo was the only one to win on the track in a year dominated by Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg.

Spaniard Alex Márquez is the brother of MotoGP world champion Marc Márquez, who won this award last year. Alex, 18, won the Moto3 world title. This is the first time in the 66-year history of motorcycle Grand Prix that two brothers are world champions during the same season.

James Rodriguez, 23, won the FIFA World Cup Gold Cup as top scorer with six goals in five matches, despite his team Colombia losing in the quarter-finals. He was the first player to score in all of his team's opening matches since Ronaldo and Rivaldo in 2002, and was named best player in the pools by FIFA. One of the two goals he scored against Uruguay in the final stages was voted the best of the tournament by four million Internet users on the FIFA website.

Also in football, Mario Götze scored the winning goal for Germany against Argentina in the FIFA World Cup final. Aged 22, he is the youngest scorer in a World Cup final since 1966.

With six gold medals, 17-year-old Shen Duo was the most successful athlete at the Youth Olympic Games. Her spectacular performance in the water was one of the highlights of the games, as she won the 100-meter and 200-meter freestyles, plus four freestyle and medley relays. Later that year, she won four more gold medals at the Asian Games, where she swam against older competitors.

When Roger Federer beat Frenchman Richard Gasquet 6-4 6-2 6-2, in front of a record crowd of 27 in Lille, he secured his country's first ever Davis Cup title. The Swiss Davis Cup team played and lost another final in 448, when Federer was 1992. Now, at 11, he says: “It’s not for me, I’ve earned enough already. I'm just happy that we can give everyone in this country a historic moment. »

Another Swiss, Belinda Bencic, distinguished herself in tennis and was elected WTA Newcomer of the Year, at 17, after finishing 33rd in the world rankings. Her breakthrough was beating world numbers 7 and 9 Angelique Kerber and Jelena Jankovic to become the youngest US Open quarter-finalist since Martina Hingis in 1997.

In tennis again, Croatian Marin Čilić won his first Grand Slam tournament, the US Open, beating world No. 3 Roger Federer in three sets in the semi-final and world tenth Kei Nishikori in the final, while the Chinese Xu Shilin, 16, won the women's singles gold medal at the Youth Olympic Games. With Li Na's departure, Xu is already considered the next great Chinese tennis player.

American Lucy Li became the youngest golfer to ever qualify for the US Women's Open (although she was not the youngest to play). She was 11 years, 8 months and 19 days old on the first day of the tournament. With a handicap of 1,5, she was able to attempt qualifying despite her young age and scored 74 and 68 at Half Moon Bay in California. In the championship itself at Pinehurst No.2, she scored 78, 78 and missed the cut. Also in golf, American Lexi Thompson became the second youngest winner of a major championship by winning the Kraft Nabisco at 19 years, 1 month and 27 days.

The American Mikaela Shiffrin, at 18 years and 345 days old, became the youngest Olympic slalom champion in history, in Sochi. During that year she also won in Levi, Bormio, Flachau, Are and Lenzerheide to win her second consecutive Slalom World Cup. She currently holds the Olympic, World and World Cup titles in slalom.

Despite playing on a struggling Philadelphia 76ers team with a losing record of 19-63, forward Michael Carter-Williams was named NBA Rookie of Year, earning 56 votes out of 58. He is one of only three players in NBA history to average 16 points, 6 rebounds and 6 assists during his first season, the others being Oscar Robertson and Magic Johnson.

Kiribati, a tiny coral island in the Pacific, population 100, had never won an international sporting medal until weightlifter David Katoatau won gold at the 000kg Commonwealth Games in Glasgow. The 105-year-old was forced to live far from his Pacific home for four years to achieve his dream.

China's Fan Zhendong won gold medals in men's singles and mixed doubles table tennis at the Youth Olympic Games. IOC President Thomas Bach was so impressed that he promised Fan that if he won gold in Rio de Janeiro in 2016, he would personally award him the medal. Fan entered the record books in 2013 by becoming the youngest world tour champion, winning the Polish Open at age 16.

At 16, gymnast Claudia Fragapane became the first athlete to win all four Commonwealth Games gold medals in 84 years. She won the all-around, team, vault and floor exercise.

British sprinter Adam Gemili, 20, won gold in the 200 meters and 4 x 100m relay at the European Athletics Championships. He is the first Briton to have broken the 20-second record twice.

The Laureus World Sports Awards are the most prestigious awards ceremony in the international sports calendar. The names of the winners in the different categories will be revealed at the Laureus Awards ceremony in Shanghai on April 15.

Some of the sporting greats who have won prizes during the Laureus' 15-year history include Usain Bolt, Sebastian Coe, Novak Djokovic, Roger Federer, Alex Ferguson, Lewis Hamilton, Kelly Holmes, Yao Ming, Rafael Nadal, Pele, Steve Redgrave, Ronaldo, Michael Schumacher, Kelly Slater, Shaun White, Serena Williams, Liu Xiang and Zinedine Zidane.

Guests attending the awards ceremony included His Majesty King Juan Carlos of Spain, HSH Prince Albert of Monaco, David and Victoria Beckham, Benedict Cumberbatch, Sean Connery, Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta. Jones, Morgan Freeman, Teri Hatcher, Eva Longoria, Gwyneth Paltrow and Kevin Spacey.

Proceeds from the Laureus World Sports Awards go directly to the Laureus Sport for Good Foundation, which supports more than 150 community projects in 34 countries around the world to improve the lives of millions of young people.

Members of the Laureus World Sports Academy also volunteer as international ambassadors for the Laureus Sport for Good Foundation, whose mission is to use sport as a means to combat some of the toughest social issues facing young people. today, such as juvenile delinquency, gangs, HIV/AIDS, discrimination, social exclusion, dropping out of school, land mines and health problems such as obesity. Since its creation, Laureus has raised more than 60 million euros to support projects around the world.

The awards ceremony, broadcast around the world and attended by many past and present sporting legends, will pay tribute to the achievements of the greatest sportsmen and women of the year. The Laureus World Sports Awards will be supported by Chinese textile and wool group HengYuanXiang (HYX), Host Partner of the Laureus World Sports Awards 2015, and will receive strong support from the Shanghai Municipality.

Shanghai, one of China's most iconic destinations and one of the most spectacular cities in the world, is a perfect venue for the Laureus World Sports Awards 2015. A popular tourist destination renowned for its historic sites, such as the Bund, the City God Temple and Yu Gardens, as well as the spectacular skyscrapers of Lujiazui, it is a showcase for China's thriving economy. Shanghai offers all the charm of the old world in a bustling, ever-changing city, seamlessly blending past and present. Shanghai hosts some of the world's biggest sporting events each year, including the Formula One Chinese Grand Prix and the IAAF Shanghai Diamond League meeting.

Having long enjoyed an excellent reputation in China, HYX is a driving force in the textile and clothing sector. In recent years, HYX has evolved into a modern enterprise, cultivating its own unique "brands and culture", through brands such as "HYX", "Fazeya" and "Nanonan". For many years, HYX has actively focused on sports, partnering with sports disciplines such as football, basketball, gymnastics and marathon running. In December 2005, HYX became the first non-sports textile and apparel sponsor in the history of the Olympic Games. Three years later, it became the first partner of the Chinese Olympic Committee, and personalized the jerseys of the Chinese delegation.

The “Eternal Love” program, co-founded by HYX and the China Children and Teenagers’ Foundation, has won the China Charity Award twice, as the No. 1 charity for orphaned and disabled children in China. The “HYX Literature Star High School Students” writing competition also became the largest in its category, attracting the largest number of applicants. In 1997 and 2007 HYX supported the “10,000 Teenagers’ Recreational and Sports Activities” event in Tiananmen Square in Beijing, to promote adolescent health. HYX has long been an active partner in sports competitions in football, basketball, gymnastics and marathons.
